key_points: President Biden discussed the ongoing efforts to evacuate American citizens, third-country civilians, Afghan allies, and vulnerable Afghans from Afghanistan.
Significant progress has been made since Biden last spoke, with secured airport allowing flights to resume and almost 6,000 troops on the ground.
Described as one of the largest, most difficult airlifts in history.
Over 18,000 people have been evacuated since July, with around 13,000 since the military airlift began on August 14.
Evacuees include American citizens, permanent residents, their families, SIV applicants, and other vulnerable Afghans.
Successful evacuation of all 204 employees of the New York Times, the Washington Post, and the Wall Street Journal.
Flights in Kabul were briefly paused to process arriving evacuees but have resumed.
U.S. is facilitating flights for Allies and partners and working in operational coordination with NATO.
Biden emphasized the evacuation mission is dangerous and cannot guarantee the final outcome will be without loss.
Continuing commitment to evacuate American citizens and Afghan allies, highlighting operational challenges and coordination with the Taliban for safe passage to the airport.
